bestBHT.bht: If we fail to be faithful in handling worldly possessions, we will not be entrusted with the true riches of God's grace. It is a sad story to witness a preacher's downfall due to the wrong use of money, falling into the snares of the devil. Our fidelity in using the unrighteous mammon demonstrates our readiness to receive spiritual and eternal treasures. The riches of this world are deceitful and unreliable, whereas the treasures of heaven are true, faithful, and never-failing.

Henry Alford: The much,—the true [riches],—that which is your own, is the true riches of God's inheritance.
...of which the earth forms a part...
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the whole of this He applies the disparaging term "what is
least," in contrast with "the true riches.
Albert Barnes: If you are not faithful in the small matters pertaining to this world, if you do not use aright your property and influence, you cannot expect that God will commit to you the true riches of his grace.
Men who are dishonest and worldly, and who do not employ the deceitful mammon as they ought, cannot expect to grow in grace.
The riches of this world are false, deceitful, not to be trusted; the treasures of heaven are 'true,' faithful, never-failing.
Marvin Vincent: Faithful. Fidelity is, therefore, possible toward the unrighteous mammon.
Archibald T. Robertson: Faithful in the unrighteous mammon (εν τω αδικω μαμωνα). In the use of what is considered 'unrighteous' as it so often is."
Condition of the first class, 'if ye did not prove to be' (ε ουκ εγενεσθε). Failure here forfeits confidence in 'the true riches' (το αληθινον).
There is no sadder story than to see a preacher go down by the wrong use of money, caught in this snare of the devil.
John Gill: If therefore ye have not been faithful... if therefore they should be unfaithful in the unrighteous mammon; who will commit to your trust the true riches?"
How should you expect to be intrusted with the riches of grace... or the riches of glory...?
And so the Syriac version renders it, 'who will trust you with the truth?' with the truth of the Gospel.
John Wesley: Who will intrust you with the true riches? — How should God intrust you with spiritual and eternal, which alone are true riches?

bhtAttempts.bht: If we cannot be faithful in using the unrighteous mammon or the earthly wealth that God has given us, how can we expect Him to entrust us with the true riches of His grace and blessings? Our fidelity in handling worldly possessions reflects our trustworthiness and readiness to receive the spiritual and eternal treasures that God desires to bestow upon us. The misuse of money can be a dangerous pitfall, particularly for preachers, and the failure to be faithful in the small matters of this world can hinder our growth in grace. Let us remember that the wealth of this world is unreliable and deceitful, while the treasures of heaven are true, faithful, and everlasting.

If we are not faithful in using the unrighteous mammon, God will not entrust us with the true riches of His grace and blessings. Our fidelity in handling earthly wealth reflects our readiness to receive spiritual treasures. Misusing money can be a snare, especially for preachers. Failing to be faithful in worldly matters hinders our growth in grace. Earthly riches are unreliable, while heavenly treasures are true and everlasting.

If we prove unfaithful in the use of worldly possessions, we forfeit the confidence of receiving the true riches from God. Mishandling money is a common danger, even for preachers, who can easily be ensnared by the devil through improper financial conduct. Our faithfulness in managing earthly wealth demonstrates our trustworthiness to receive the spiritual treasures that God desires to bestow upon us. The riches of this world are deceitful and untrustworthy, but the treasures of heaven are faithful and eternal.

If we fail to be faithful in handling worldly possessions, we will not be entrusted with the true riches of God's grace. It is a sad story to witness a preacher's downfall due to the wrong use of money, falling into the snares of the devil. Our fidelity in using the unrighteous mammon demonstrates our readiness to receive spiritual and eternal treasures. The riches of this world are deceitful and unreliable, whereas the treasures of heaven are true, faithful, and never-failing.

If our faithfulness is lacking in handling worldly possessions, we cannot expect God to entrust us with the true riches of His grace. It is a sad sight to see a preacher succumb to the snare of the devil through misusing money. Our ability to be faithful in the unrighteous mammon reflects our trustworthiness to receive the spiritual treasures that God desires to bestow upon us. Earthly riches are deceitful and untrustworthy, while the treasures of heaven are true, faithful, and eternal.
